Abstract Abstract
This document defines requirements for standards specifications for This document defines requirements for standards specifications for
Energy Management. The requirements defined in this document are Energy Management, taking RFC6988 as a starting point. Eleven years
concerned with monitoring functions as well as control functions. after the RFC 6988 publication, this document re-evaluate the
Monitoring functions include identifying energy-managed devices and requirements. The requirements defined in this document are
their components, as well as monitoring their Power States, Power concerned with discovery functions, monitoring functions as well as
Inlets, Power Outlets, actual power, Power Attributes, received control functions. Discovery functions include identifying energy-
energy, provided energy, and contained batteries. Control functions managed network, devices and their components and discovery of
include such functions as controlling power supply and Power State of inventory of power components capabilities, optimization control
energy-managed devices and their components. capabilities, nominal condition use. Monitoring functions include
monitoring their Power States, Power Attributes, energy consumption,
energy efficiency metrics. Control functions include such functions
as controlling energy saving and optimization functions and Power
State of energy-managed devices and their components.
This document does not specify the features that must be implemented This document does not specify the features that must be implemented
by compliant implementations but rather lists features that must be by compliant implementations but rather lists features that must be
supported by standards for Energy Management. supported by standards for Energy efficiency Management.

1. Introduction 1. In Preparation of the GREEN BoF at IETF 120
The EMAN (Energy MANagement) working, created in 2010 and now
concluded, has produced multiples RFCs
o RFC 7603, Energy Management (EMAN) Applicability Statement
o RFC 7577, Definition of Managed Objects for Battery Monitoring
o RFC 7460, Monitoring and Control MIB for Power and Energy
o RFC 7461, Energy Object Context MIB
o RFC 7326, Energy Management Framework
o RFC 6988, Requirements for Energy Management
o RFC 6933, Entity MIB (Version 4)
Note also that some other energy-related MIB modules have been
created, but not by the EMAN Working Group
o Entity Sensor MIB module defined in RFC3433
o Power Ethernet MIB module defined in RFC3621
o UPS Power Monitoring MIB module defined in RFC1628
o LLDP MIB module and LLDP MED MIB module
Due to limitation of Writeable MIB module, one IESG statement
published in 2014 encourages the use the NETCONF/YANG standards for
configuration. Based on the YANG modules developments, 3 MIB modules
(Entity MIB module, Entity Sensor MIB module, Entity State MIB
module) have been transormed ino the "YANG Data Model for Hardware
Management" RFC8348.
However Power and Energy Monitoring and Control MIB module hasn't
been transformed yet into YANG modules.
Eleven years after the EMAN requirements RFC 6988 publication, this
document re-evaluates the energy-related requirements, as a
preparation for the GREEN BoF at IETF 120.

ecological impact of running information technology equipment, Energy ecological impact of running information technology equipment, Energy
Management (EMAN) functions and interfaces are becoming an additional efficiency Management functions and management interfaces are
basic requirement for network management systems and devices becoming an additional basic requirement for network management
connected to a network. systems and devices connected to a network.

2. Terminology 3. Terminology
The terms specified in the terminology section are capitalized The terms specified in the terminology section are capitalized
throughout the document; the exceptions are the well-known terms throughout the document; the exceptions are the well-known terms
"energy" and "power". These terms are generic and are used in "energy" and "power". These terms are generic and are used in
generated terms such as "energy-saving", "low-power", etc. generated terms such as "energy-saving", "low-power", etc.
Energy Energy
Energy is the capacity of a system to do work. As used by Energy is the capacity of a system to do work. As used by
electric utilities, it is generally a reference to electrical electric utilities, it is generally a reference to electrical
energy and is measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh) [IEEE-100]. energy and is measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh) [IEEE-100].
Power Power
Power is the time rate at which energy is emitted, transferred, or Power is the time rate at which energy is emitted, transferred, or
received; power is usually expressed in watts (or in joules per received; power is usually expressed in watts (or in joules per
second) [IEEE-100]. (The term "power" does not refer to the second) [IEEE-100]. (The term "power" does not refer to the
concept of demand, which is an averaged power value.) concept of demand, which is an averaged power value.)
Power Attributes Power Attributes
Power Attributes are measurements of electric current, voltage,
phase, and frequencies at a given point in an electrical power
system (adapted from [IEC.60050]).
Power Attributes are measurements of electric current, voltage, NOTE: Power Attributes are not intended to be "judgmental" with
phase, and frequencies at a given point in an electrical power respect to a reference or technical value and are independent of
system (adapted from [IEC.60050]). any usage context.
NOTE: Power Attributes are not intended to be "judgmental" with
respect to a reference or technical value and are independent of
any usage context.
Energy Management Energy Management
Energy Management is a set of functions for measuring, modeling, Energy Management is a set of functions for measuring, modeling,
planning, and optimizing networks to ensure that the network planning, and optimizing networks to ensure that the network
elements and attached devices use energy efficiently and in a elements use energy efficiently and in a
manner appropriate to the nature of the application and the cost manner appropriate to the nature of the application and the cost
constraints of the organization [ITU-M.3400]. constraints of the organization [ITU-M.3400].
Energy Efficiency Management
Involves deploying and managing network infrastructures with the
goal of optimizing energy use on network devices while improving
the overall network utilization.
Energy Management System Energy Management System
An Energy Management System is a combination of hardware and An Energy Management System is a combination of hardware and
software used to administer a network with the primary purpose software used to administer a network with the primary purpose
being Energy Management. being Energy Management.
Energy Monitoring Energy Monitoring
Energy Monitoring is a part of Energy Management that deals with Energy Monitoring is a part of Energy Efficiency Management that deals with
collecting or reading information from network elements and collecting or reading information from network elements and their components to aid in
attached devices and their components to aid in Energy Management. Energy Efficiency Management.
Energy Control Energy Control
Energy Control is a part of Energy Management that deals with Energy Control is a part of Energy Management that deals with
controlling energy supply and Power State of network elements, as controlling energy supply and Power State of network elements, as
well as attached devices and their components. well as their components.
Power Interface Power Interface
A Power Interface is an interface at which a device is connected A Power Interface is an interface at which a device is connected
to a power transmission medium, at which it can in turn receive to a power transmission medium, at which it can in turn receive
power, provide power, or both. power, provide power, or both.
Power Inlet Power Inlet
A Power Inlet is a Power Interface at which a device can receive
A Power Inlet is a Power Interface at which a device can receive power from other devices.
power from other devices.
Power Outlet Power Outlet
A Power Outlet is a Power Interface at which a device can provide A Power Outlet is a Power Interface at which a device can provide
power to other devices. power to other devices.
Power State Power State
A Power State is a condition or mode of a device that broadly A Power State is a condition or mode of a device that broadly
characterizes its capabilities, power consumption, and characterizes its capabilities, power consumption, and
responsiveness to input [IEEE-1621]. responsiveness to input [IEEE-1621].
3. General Considerations Related to Energy Management 4. High-level Differences with RFC6988
The basic objective of Energy Management is to operate sets of The following section will delve into the specific details but from a
devices using minimal energy, while maintaining a certain level of high level point of view, the differences between this document and
service. [EMAN-STATEMENT] presents the applicability of the EMAN the RFC6988 are:
framework to a variety of scenarios and also lists use cases and
target devices.
3.1. Power States - new definition for "Energy Efficiency Management"
- a focus towards YANG, and not any longer on MIB modules
- as a consequence from the previous point, the ENTITY-MIB v4 (RFC6933) is replaced by the Hardware YANG module RFC8348
- less focus on the battery management (as batteries haves some self-optimization features these days)
- less focus on the Power over Ethernet management
5. General Considerations Related to Energy Management
The basic objective of Energy Efficiency Management is to operate
sets of network devices using minimal energy, while maintaining a
certain level of service.
5.1. Power States
Entities can be set to an operational state that results in the Entities can be set to an operational state that results in the
lowest power level that still meets the service-level performance lowest power level that still meets the service-level performance
objectives. In principle, there are three basic types of Power objectives. In principle, there are three basic types of Power
States for an entity or for a whole system: States for an entity or for a whole system:
o full Power State o full Power State
o sleep state (not functional but immediately available) o sleep state (not functional but immediately available)
o off state (may require significant time to become operational) o off state (may require significant time to become operational)
In specific network devices, the number of Power States and their
properties vary considerably. Simple entities may only have the
extreme states: full Power State and off state. Many network devices
have three basic Power States: on, off, and sleep. However, more
finely grained Power States can be implemented, especially when
Energy efficiency gains for communication systems are highly sought
after, for environmental, business, and technical reasons. Examples
are various operational low Power States in which a network device
requires less energy than in the full power "on" state, but --
compared to the sleep state -- is still operational with reduced
performance or functionality.
In specific devices, the number of Power States and their properties Another example is standby power state in which network device has
vary considerably. Simple entities may only have the extreme states: multiple standby components and one active component for the same
full Power State and off state. Many devices have three basic Power functionality, standby components are partially functional and can be
States: on, off, and sleep. However, more finely grained Power immediately available when active component is down. The standby
States can be implemented. Examples are various operational low power state can be introduced to save energy while impove the overall
Power States in which a device requires less energy than in the full network utilization.
power "on" state, but -- compared to the sleep state -- is still
operational with reduced performance or functionality.

consumption. While this objective is clear, attaining that goal is energy consumption. While this objective is clear, attaining that
often difficult. In many cases, there is no way to reduce power goal is often difficult. In many cases, there is no way to reduce
without the consequence of a potential service (performance or power without the consequence of a potential service (performance or
capacity) degradation. In this case, a trade-off needs to be made capacity) degradation. In this case, a trade-off needs to be made
between service-level objectives and energy minimization. In other between service-level objectives (e.g., network performance) and
cases, a reduction of power can easily be achieved while still energy minimization. In other cases, a reduction of power can easily
maintaining sufficient service-level performance, for example, by be achieved while still maintaining sufficient service-level
switching entities to lower Power States when higher performance is performance, for example, by switching entities to lower Power States
not needed. when higher performance is not needed. To measure of the trade-off
between service-level object and energy consumption, a new set of
energy efficiency metrics needs to defined.

requirements in Section 5.5.3. requirements in Section 5.5.3.

5.5. Energy 7.5. Energy
The monitoring of electrical energy received or provided by an entity The monitoring of electrical energy received or provided by an entity
is a core function of Energy Management. Since energy is an is a core function of Energy Management. Since energy is an
accumulated quantity, it is always reported for a certain interval of accumulated quantity, it is always reported for a certain interval of
time. This can be, for example, the time from the last restart of time. This can be, for example, the time from the last restart of
the entity to the reporting time, the time from another past event to the entity to the reporting time, the time from another past event to
the reporting time, the last given amount of time before the the reporting time, the last given amount of time before the
reporting time, or a certain interval specified by two timestamps in reporting time, or a certain interval specified by two timestamps in
the past. the past.
It is useful for entities to record their received and provided It is useful for entities to record their received and provided
energy per Power State and report these quantities. energy per Power State and report these quantities.
5.5.1. Energy Measurement In addition, it is also useful for entities to record energy
attributes such as maximum wake up time, maximum sleep time, service
interruption time, transition time, maximum packet throughput,
maximum bit throughput and report these quantities.
7.5.1. Energy Measurement
The standard must provide means for reporting measured values of The standard must provide means for reporting measured values of
energy and the direction of the energy flow received or provided by energy and the direction of the energy flow received or provided by
an entity. The standard must also provide the means to report the an entity. The standard must also provide the means to report the
energy passing through each Power Interface. energy passing through each Power Interface.
5.5.2. Time Intervals 7.5.2. Energy Efficiency Measurement
The standard must provide means for measuring the trade-off between
service-level object and energy consumption. [ETSI-ES-203-136],
[ITUT-L.1310], [ATIS-0600015.03.2013] provide methodology and test
procedure for measuring such energy efficiency related metrics, which
is defined as the throughput forwarded by 1 watt. The traffic loads
and the weighted multipliers need to be clearly established in
advance.
7.5.3. Power Gain Measurement
The standard must provide means for measuing power gain, which can be
calculated by actual power to be consumed by the entity divided by
the maximum power of the entity. In addition, the minimum power gain
can also be meaured and reported.
7.5.4. Time Intervals
The standard must provide means for reporting the time interval for The standard must provide means for reporting the time interval for
which an energy value is reported. which an energy value is reported.
5.5.3. Energy Per Power State 7.5.5. Energy Per Power State
The standard must provide means for reporting the received and The standard must provide means for reporting the received and
provided energy for each individual Power State. This extends the provided energy for each individual Power State. This extends the
requirements on Power State statistics described in Section 5.4.7. requirements on Power State statistics described in Section 5.4.7.
5.6. Battery State 7.6. Obsolete Battery State from RFC6988
Batteries are special entities that supply power. The status of
these batteries is typically controlled by automatic functions that
act locally on the entity, and manually by users of the entity.
There is a need to monitor the battery status of these entities by
network management systems.
Devices containing batteries can be modeled in two ways. The entire
device can be modeled as a single entity on which energy-related
information is reported, or the battery can be modeled as an
individual entity for which energy-related information is monitored
individually according to requirements in Sections 5.1 through 5.5.
Further information on batteries is of interest for Energy
Management, such as the current charge of the battery, the number of
completed charging cycles, the charging state of the battery, its
temperature, and additional static and dynamic battery properties.
It is desirable to receive notifications if the charge of a battery
becomes very low or if a battery needs to be replaced.
5.6.1. Battery Charge
The standard must provide means for reporting the current charge of a
battery, in units of milliampere-hours (mAh).
5.6.2. Battery Charging State
The standard must provide means for reporting the charging state
(charging, discharging, etc.) of a battery.
5.6.3. Battery Charging Cycles
The standard must provide means for reporting the number of completed
charging cycles of a battery.
5.6.4. Actual Battery Capacity
The standard must provide means for reporting the actual capacity of
a battery.
5.6.5. Actual Battery Temperature
The standard must provide means for reporting the actual temperature
of a battery.
5.6.6. Static Battery Properties
The standard must provide means for reporting static properties of a
battery, including the nominal capacity, the number of cells, the
nominal voltage, and the battery technology.
5.6.7. Low Battery Charge Notification
The standard must provide means for generating a notification when
the charge of a battery decreases below a given threshold. Note that
the threshold may depend on the battery technology.
5.6.8. Battery Replacement Notification
The standard must provide means for generating a notification when
the number of charging cycles of a battery exceeds a given threshold.
5.6.9. Multiple Batteries Batteries are built in component within a network device and have no
difference with other built in components such as power supply.
Therefore there is no need to monitor the battery status of these
entities by network management systems separately.
If the battery technology allows, the standard must provide means for This document proposes to obsolete battery state from RFC6988.
meeting requirements in Sections 5.6.1 through 5.6.8 for each
individual battery contained in a single entity.

9. Security Considerations 11. Security Considerations
Controlling Power State and power supply of entities are considered Controlling Power State and power supply of entities are considered
highly sensitive actions, since they can significantly affect the highly sensitive actions, since they can significantly affect the
operation of directly and indirectly connected devices. Therefore, operation of directly and indirectly connected devices. Therefore,
all control actions addressed in Sections 6 and 8 must be all control actions addressed in Sections 6 and 8 must be
sufficiently protected through authentication, authorization, and sufficiently protected through authentication, authorization, and
integrity protection mechanisms. integrity protection mechanisms.
Entities that are not sufficiently secure to operate directly on the Entities that are not sufficiently secure to operate directly on the
public Internet do exist and can be a significant cause of risk, for public Internet do exist and can be a significant cause of risk, for
skipping to change at page 24, line 26 ¶ skipping to change at page 28, line 10 ¶
in Sections 5 through 8 can be used to derive more information than in Sections 5 through 8 can be used to derive more information than
just the received and provided energy; therefore, monitored data just the received and provided energy; therefore, monitored data
requires protection. This protection includes authentication and requires protection. This protection includes authentication and
authorization of entities requesting access to monitored data as well authorization of entities requesting access to monitored data as well
as confidentiality protection during transmission of monitored data. as confidentiality protection during transmission of monitored data.
Privacy of stored data in an entity must be taken into account. Privacy of stored data in an entity must be taken into account.
Monitored data may be used as input to control, accounting, and other Monitored data may be used as input to control, accounting, and other
actions, so integrity of transmitted information and authentication actions, so integrity of transmitted information and authentication
of the origin may be needed. of the origin may be needed.
9.1. Secure Energy Management 11.1. Secure Energy Management
The standard must provide privacy, integrity, and authentication The standard must provide privacy, integrity, and authentication
mechanisms for all actions addressed in Sections 5 through 8. The mechanisms for all actions addressed in Sections 5 through 8. The
security mechanisms must meet the security requirements detailed in security mechanisms must meet the security requirements detailed in
Section 1.4 of [RFC3411]. Section 1.4 of [RFC3411].
9.2. Isolation of Insufficiently Secure Entities 11.2. Isolation of Insufficiently Secure Entities
The standard must provide means to allow the isolation of entities The standard must provide means to allow the isolation of entities
that are not sufficiently secure to operate on the public Internet, that are not sufficiently secure to operate on the public Internet,
e.g., behind a gateway that implements sufficient security that the e.g., behind a gateway that implements sufficient security that the
vulnerable entities are not directly exposed to the Internet. vulnerable entities are not directly exposed to the Internet.
9.3. Optional Restriction of Functions 11.3. Optional Restriction of Functions
The standard must allow compliant implementations to disable The standard must allow compliant implementations to disable
sensitive functions, or to not implement such functions at all, when sensitive functions, or to not implement such functions at all, when
operating in environments that are not sufficiently secured. This operating in environments that are not sufficiently secured. This
applies particularly to the control functions described in Sections 6 applies particularly to the control functions described in Sections 6
